story: An apprentice wrote a spell to collect items, using a list as a default argument. The spell behaves strangely when called multiple times...
instructions: Predict the output. This function has a mutable default argument. Watch what happens across multiple calls!

hints.text: Default arguments are evaluated ONCE when the function is defined, not every time it's called.
The `bag=[]` creates a single list object at definition time. Every call that uses the default shares this same list!
When you pass an explicit argument (Call 4), it uses that list instead of the shared default. But Call 5 goes back to the shared default.

solutionHidden:
def collect(item, bag=[]):
    bag.append(item)
    return bag

print(f"Call 1: {collect('sword')}")
print(f"Call 2: {collect('shield')}")
print(f"Call 3: {collect('potion')}")

# With explicit argument
my_bag = []
print(f"Call 4: {collect('scroll', my_bag)}")
print(f"Call 5: {collect('map')}")
title: The Default Mutable Argument Trap
